item.title: Test server no './amaze' file
item.description:
I'm having an issue getting my project to run successfully on the test server. I can test the compilation and the project compiles with no problems. However, when I submit to the test server all the tests that require ./amaze fail with the error: timeout: failed to run command ‘./amaze’: No such file or directory.

I am able to compile/run my project on my own computer without problems, except for when I use "make test". When I run "make test" on my computer it gets and error "make: *** [test] Error 255" when it tries to run ./amaze without any command line arguments. If I run ./amaze with arguments it runs fine.

I'm sure the problems are likely related but ultimately not sure what is causing the problem. I've been changing around my makefile but nothing has fixed the issue. 

If anyone has had a similar problem or any pointers I would appreciate it.
item.content:encoded:
I'm having an issue getting my project to run successfully on the test server. I can test the compilation and the project compiles with no problems. However, when I submit to the test server all the tests that require ./amaze fail with the error: timeout: failed to run command ‘./amaze’: No such file or directory.

I am able to compile/run my project on my own computer without problems, except for when I use "make test". When I run "make test" on my computer it gets and error "make: *** [test] Error 255" when it tries to run ./amaze without any command line arguments. If I run ./amaze with arguments it runs fine.

I'm sure the problems are likely related but ultimately not sure what is causing the problem. I've been changing around my makefile but nothing has fixed the issue. 

If anyone has had a similar problem or any pointers I would appreciate it.

item.title: CreateMaze Exit
item.description: So when I create my maze, should I consider the exit as a neighbor of Cell[cols-1][rows-1], or should I just automatically 'open' it? This is important, because it changes the way the pseudo-random maze would be written.
item.content:encoded: So when I create my maze, should I consider the exit as a neighbor of Cell[cols-1][rows-1], or should I just automatically 'open' it? This is important, because it changes the way the pseudo-random maze would be written.

item.title: Passing free functions to setSTACKfree/setQUEUEfree
item.description: Whenever I pass my freeMAZE function to setSTACKfree or setQUEUEfree, I get a warning "incompatible pointer types passing 'void (MAZE *)' to parameter of type 'void (*)(void *)'. I am passing the function in the way assign0 specified. Do I need a wrapper function in order to silence this warning, change my MAZE * to void * in my freeMAZE function, or something else?
item.content:encoded: Whenever I pass my freeMAZE function to setSTACKfree or setQUEUEfree, I get a warning "incompatible pointer types passing 'void (MAZE *)' to parameter of type 'void (*)(void *)'. I am passing the function in the way assign0 specified. Do I need a wrapper function in order to silence this warning, change my MAZE * to void * in my freeMAZE function, or something else?

item.title: Largest Possible Maze
item.description:
Quote:No limit on number of rows and number of columns.
When I try ./amaze -d test -c 10000 10000 test -s test test,
it ate over 16GB memory and then showed "Segmentation fault (core dumped)"

What is the largest possible maze during grading? Is there a limit of memory used for the program? Thanks.

Updated 10/11/2018: I have optimized my code and it can handle 10000 * 10000 maze now, which consumes 9.3GB memory, occupies 2.23GB disk space, takes 11.87 mins to run includes printing.
item.content:encoded:
Quote:No limit on number of rows and number of columns.
When I try ./amaze -d test -c 10000 10000 test -s test test,
it ate over 16GB memory and then showed "Segmentation fault (core dumped)"

What is the largest possible maze during grading? Is there a limit of memory used for the program? Thanks.

Updated 10/11/2018: I have optimized my code and it can handle 10000 * 10000 maze now, which consumes 9.3GB memory, occupies 2.23GB disk space, takes 11.87 mins to run includes printing.

item.title: Help debugging my neighbors array
item.description:
Hi, could anyone help debug why the count of my neighbors array (the number of neighbors for any particular cell) is not being updated, even when it seemingly is?

A picture of what my debugger output looks like is attached. You can see in my helper function "setCELLNeighbors" that each cell is being read into the function and has the correct number of neighbors (testing with a 3x3 matrix--I went through by hand and verified that each cell should have the number of neighbors that my program is outputting). However, when I want to find an eligible neighbor to remove its wall, my findNeighbor function is claiming that the CELL argument has a neighbor count of 0... the first cell to be passed to the findNeighbor function is the cell at (0, 0)-- which, in my setCELLNeighbors function, ostensibly has the correct number of neighbors (2). Any idea why this might be happening and where I should look to solve it?

  Screen Shot 2018-10-10 at 12.10.54.png (Size: 132.96 KB / Downloads: 15)
item.content:encoded:
Hi, could anyone help debug why the count of my neighbors array (the number of neighbors for any particular cell) is not being updated, even when it seemingly is?

A picture of what my debugger output looks like is attached. You can see in my helper function "setCELLNeighbors" that each cell is being read into the function and has the correct number of neighbors (testing with a 3x3 matrix--I went through by hand and verified that each cell should have the number of neighbors that my program is outputting). However, when I want to find an eligible neighbor to remove its wall, my findNeighbor function is claiming that the CELL argument has a neighbor count of 0... the first cell to be passed to the findNeighbor function is the cell at (0, 0)-- which, in my setCELLNeighbors function, ostensibly has the correct number of neighbors (2). Any idea why this might be happening and where I should look to solve it?

  Screen Shot 2018-10-10 at 12.10.54.png (Size: 132.96 KB / Downloads: 15)

item.title: If we create a different, correct, maze, is it wrong?
item.description: If we create a maze that is valid (no unvisited spots, constant line from entry to exit, proper size) is it wrong if it doesn't match the ones in the drop box? Do we need to use Lusth's algorithm exactly to create our mazes?
item.content:encoded: If we create a maze that is valid (no unvisited spots, constant line from entry to exit, proper size) is it wrong if it doesn't match the ones in the drop box? Do we need to use Lusth's algorithm exactly to create our mazes?

item.title: Beware
item.description:
A couple of students were getting different mazes that what the test1 dropbox indicated.

This was because they only pushed a cell onto the stack only once. If you pop a cell and it has more than one eligible neighbor, it needs to pushed back onto the stack before the chosen neighbor.

Or you could peek, count neighbors, push a neighbor if any exist, otherwise pop.
item.content:encoded:
A couple of students were getting different mazes that what the test1 dropbox indicated.

This was because they only pushed a cell onto the stack only once. If you pop a cell and it has more than one eligible neighbor, it needs to pushed back onto the stack before the chosen neighbor.

Or you could peek, count neighbors, push a neighbor if any exist, otherwise pop.

item.title: Purpose of argIndex in options.c
item.description:
In ProcessOptions we return argIndex. But why? What's the purpose of that value and what should we do with it?

if (argIndex == argc) {printf("No arguments?\n");}

The above line will always trigger even though everything else works fine. If I get rid of it, what is processoption supposed to return? In main we set argIndex = processoptions(); 

Can't we just call processoptions(); Why does it need to return anything?
item.content:encoded:
In ProcessOptions we return argIndex. But why? What's the purpose of that value and what should we do with it?

if (argIndex == argc) {printf("No arguments?\n");}

The above line will always trigger even though everything else works fine. If I get rid of it, what is processoption supposed to return? In main we set argIndex = processoptions(); 

Can't we just call processoptions(); Why does it need to return anything?

item.title: One more clarification about using random
item.description:
I know this has been addressed somewhere else on the forum previously, but I am still confused as to when to use random when creating/building a maze. Different options:

1) We use just one value to seed the random number generator for the whole maze, and we then only use the random number generator once for the whole maze. (I don't think this is intended at all.)

2) Any time we need to pick a new eligible neighbor, we generate a new random number using the same seed value from the beginning, and this seed value never changes throughout the creation of the maze. It can be given via the -r option or default to 1. The seed value is never generated by a random number generator with another seed value (i.e. we never use a random number generator to seed another random number generator). The randomness of this approach stems from what the value of count is. Once we find the direction we need to take, we follow this direction until we hit an ineligible neighbor, and then we retrace. (I think this is wrong because it would just create a spiral of a maze, and not a random maze.)

3) The same logic as (2), but instead of following the same direction until we hit an ineligible neighbor, every time we have to choose a new eligible neighbor, we generate a new random number that decides. (I think this is what is intended.)

I think that (2) is what Dr. Lusth intends, but I want to be 100% certain. If anyone could confirm? Thanks!
item.content:encoded:
I know this has been addressed somewhere else on the forum previously, but I am still confused as to when to use random when creating/building a maze. Different options:

1) We use just one value to seed the random number generator for the whole maze, and we then only use the random number generator once for the whole maze. (I don't think this is intended at all.)

2) Any time we need to pick a new eligible neighbor, we generate a new random number using the same seed value from the beginning, and this seed value never changes throughout the creation of the maze. It can be given via the -r option or default to 1. The seed value is never generated by a random number generator with another seed value (i.e. we never use a random number generator to seed another random number generator). The randomness of this approach stems from what the value of count is. Once we find the direction we need to take, we follow this direction until we hit an ineligible neighbor, and then we retrace. (I think this is wrong because it would just create a spiral of a maze, and not a random maze.)

3) The same logic as (2), but instead of following the same direction until we hit an ineligible neighbor, every time we have to choose a new eligible neighbor, we generate a new random number that decides. (I think this is what is intended.)

I think that (2) is what Dr. Lusth intends, but I want to be 100% certain. If anyone could confirm? Thanks!

item.title: Command Line Arguments
item.description: For the command line arguments are we to expect two different forms of input? Ex. -c 10 10 m.data, -c10 10 m.data. I noticed that in the options.c given to us it has both options as an expected input. In the description of assign1 it doesn't mention this and I would like to know if I should have to include both inputs as an option.
item.content:encoded: For the command line arguments are we to expect two different forms of input? Ex. -c 10 10 m.data, -c10 10 m.data. I noticed that in the options.c given to us it has both options as an expected input. In the description of assign1 it doesn't mention this and I would like to know if I should have to include both inputs as an option.

item.title: Helpful Hint
item.description: Just to help people out, when you are doing -s, if the file you are reading from and writing to are the same, you will need to make sure to close the read version before you open the write version. I did it the other way initially and got a segfault when testing against one of the student provided test cases. I don't know if Dr. Lusth will be testing for the ability to handle both files being the same file, but doing this expands your functionality. Good luck on y'alls projects.
item.content:encoded: Just to help people out, when you are doing -s, if the file you are reading from and writing to are the same, you will need to make sure to close the read version before you open the write version. I did it the other way initially and got a segfault when testing against one of the student provided test cases. I don't know if Dr. Lusth will be testing for the ability to handle both files being the same file, but doing this expands your functionality. Good luck on y'alls projects.

item.title: Queue Valgrind Errors
item.description: When solving the maze, I'm successfully freeing the queue used and not getting any memory leaks and the logic is working correctly. For some reason I am getting many valgrind errors that say "Invalid read of size 8" and "Address is 0 bytes after a block of size 0 alloc'd". Anyone else getting the same error? It confuses me as my queue passed all the assign0 tests.
item.content:encoded: When solving the maze, I'm successfully freeing the queue used and not getting any memory leaks and the logic is working correctly. For some reason I am getting many valgrind errors that say "Invalid read of size 8" and "Address is 0 bytes after a block of size 0 alloc'd". Anyone else getting the same error? It confuses me as my queue passed all the assign0 tests.

item.title: options.c and main.c
item.description: I'm confused as to how you intend us to integrate options.c. I understand that it will handle all the options for us, but what I don't get is how that works with the libraries we are writing. Is your thought process that we will edit options.c to call the functions necessary based upon what it reads in, that we will call options.c from our own main, or that we take options.c and write it into our main?
item.content:encoded: I'm confused as to how you intend us to integrate options.c. I understand that it will handle all the options for us, but what I don't get is how that works with the libraries we are writing. Is your thought process that we will edit options.c to call the functions necessary based upon what it reads in, that we will call options.c from our own main, or that we take options.c and write it into our main?

item.title: problems with random and -std=C99
item.description:
I have
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

in my code, but when I use the random() function I get 
warning: implicit declaration of function ‘random’ [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]

I googled it, and a stackoverflow question gave me this answer:
man srandom says that the function is not part of C99 but part of POSIX.

How do I reconcile that with "You must implement your modules in C99 and you must use the -std=C99 option to gcc in your makefile."? Should we use rand() instead of random()? As far as I can tell the code still works, but it always compiles with a warning.
Edit: got my question answered. You have to put
extern void srandom(unsigned int);
extern long int random(void);
at the top of the file
item.content:encoded:
I have
#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

in my code, but when I use the random() function I get 
warning: implicit declaration of function ‘random’ [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]

I googled it, and a stackoverflow question gave me this answer:
man srandom says that the function is not part of C99 but part of POSIX.

How do I reconcile that with "You must implement your modules in C99 and you must use the -std=C99 option to gcc in your makefile."? Should we use rand() instead of random()? As far as I can tell the code still works, but it always compiles with a warning.
Edit: got my question answered. You have to put
extern void srandom(unsigned int);
extern long int random(void);
at the top of the file

item.description:
Hi, could someone clarify what "wall info" means within our CELL objects? Are we basing that wall info off of that particular CELL's adjacent CELLs? Or something else?

Thank you!
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Maze building and solving animation
item.description: I've created an animation of the building and solving of a maze and thought some may find it useful to visualize what is going on.  When building the maze, the 0 marks what cell you are inside.  The color of the 0 changes every time a wall is removed.  When the 0 backs up while staying the same color, that means there are no eligible neighbors from which to remove a wall, and the stack is popping until a cell with an eligible neighbor is found.
item.content:encoded: I've created an animation of the building and solving of a maze and thought some may find it useful to visualize what is going on.  When building the maze, the 0 marks what cell you are inside.  The color of the 0 changes every time a wall is removed.  When the 0 backs up while staying the same color, that means there are no eligible neighbors from which to remove a wall, and the stack is popping until a cell with an eligible neighbor is found.
